#Text=Calculate a Light Year
#Text=At first glance , you may think that a light year is a measure of time given that it has the word year in it .
#Text=Light years are actually a measure of distance that uses light as a standard .
#Text=If you have ever told a friend you are about five minutes away , you have also used time as a measure of distance .
#Text=The distances between stars across the universe are very great , so astronomers use light years as a larger unit than miles or kilometers .
#Text=To calculate the actual distance of a light year , you simply need to multiply the speed of light by the number of seconds in a year .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Calculating a Light Year
#Text=Define the light year .
#Text=A light year is a measure of distance equal to how far light travels in one Earth year .
#Text=Because distances across the universe are so large , astronomers use light years .
#Text=Without light years , discussing the distance between two stars would require the use of large , unruly numbers .
#Text=Another measure of distance you may come across when learning astronomy is the parsec .
#Text=It is equal to 3.26 light years .
#Text=It is another way to simplify the numbers used to calculate and discuss astronomical distances .
#Text=Write the formula for distance .
#Text=Using the common physics formula , distance equals rate times time or d = r x t , you can calculate how long a light year is : Light Year = ( speed of light ) x ( one year ) .
#Text=Since speed of light is represented by the variable “ c ” , you can rewrite the equation as d = c x t , where d is the distance of a light year , c is the speed of light and t is time .
#Text=If you want to know the distance of a light year in kilometers , you will need to find the speed of light in kilometers per second .
#Text=If you want miles , you will need the speed of light in miles per second .
#Text=You need to know the number of seconds in one Earth year for this calculation .
#Text=Define the speed of light .
#Text=Light in a vacuum travels at a velocity of 186,000 miles per second .
#Text=This is the equivalent of 299,792 kilometers per second or 670,616,629 miles per hour .
#Text=Here we will use the velocity in miles-per-second .
#Text=For this calculation we will use the speed of light , c , equals 186,000 miles per second .
#Text=This can be rewritten in scientific notation as 1.86 x 105 miles per second .
#Text=Calculate the number of seconds in a year .
#Text=To find the number of seconds in a year , you will do a series of multiplications by conversions units .

#Text=To convert years to seconds you will multiply the number of days in a year times the number of hours in a day , times the number of minutes in an hour , times the number of seconds in a minute .
#Text=1 year x 365 days/year x 24 hours/day x 60 minutes/hour x 60 seconds/minute = 31,536,000 seconds .
#Text=Again , we can rewrite this large number using scientific notation as 3.154 x 107 .
#Text=Plug variables into equation and solve .
#Text=Now that you have defined the variables for speed of light and time , you can plug them into the equation d = c x t and solve for the distance of a light year .
#Text=Replace c with 1.86 x 105 miles per second and time with 3.15 x 107 seconds .
#Text=d = c x t
#Text=d = ( 1.86 x 105 ) x ( 3.154 x 107 seconds )
#Text=d = 5.8 x 1012 or 5.8 trillion miles .
#Text=Calculate the distance in kilometers .
#Text=If you wanted to calculate in kilometers , simply replace the speed of light with the speed in kilometers per second : 3.00 x 105 .
#Text=The time in seconds remains the same because there is no conversion required .
#Text=d = c x t
#Text=d = ( 3.00 x 105 ) x ( 3.154 x 107 seconds )
#Text=d = 9.46 x 1012 or 9.5 trillion kilometers .
#Text=Converting Distances to Light Years
#Text=Identify the distance you want to convert .
#Text=Before you begin , you will want to make sure that whatever distance you are working with is either in miles ( if using Imperial units ) or in kilometers if working with metric .
#Text=It does n’t make much sense to convert smaller distances into light years , but you can if you ’re curious .
#Text=To convert feet into miles , remember that there are 5,280 feet in a mile : x ft ( 1 mile/5280 ft ) = miles .
#Text=To convert meters into kilometers , simply divide by 1000 : x m ( 1 km/1000 m ) = km .
#Text=Determine the correct conversion factor .
#Text=You need to identify the units for the distance that you ’re converting to light years .
#Text=If you ’re converting from kilometers to light years , you will use a different conversion factor than if you ’re converting from miles .
#Text=To convert from kilometers to light years , you will use : 1 light year/(9.46 x 1012 km ) .
#Text=To convert from miles to light years , you will use : 1 light year/(5.88 x 1012 miles ) .
#Text=Multiply the original distance by the conversion factor .
#Text=Once you have determined the proper conversion factor , you can multiply by the original distance to obtain the distance in light years .
#Text=When numbers are large , it is best to use scientific notation .
#Text=For example :
#Text=If you knew that an object was approximately 14.2 x 1014 miles away from Earth , how many light years would that be ?
#Text=Use the miles conversion factor : 1/(5.88 x 1012 )
#Text=The object is 241 light years away .
#Text=Find help .
#Text=You can always ask for assistance from your teacher and fellow students .
#Text=There are also many resources online and in your text book to help you when converting to light years .
#Text=Do n’t hesitate to ask for extra help if you need it .
#Text=Remember , there are always multiple ways to get help when looking for an answer .
